title: How to Connect a PlayStation 4 to Speakers

steps.headline: Buy an optical audio cable.
steps.description: These cables have a hexagonal plastic mouth with a small jack in the middle. You can typically find them in tech departments of retail stores, or on Amazon. The PS4 Slim doesn't have an optical audio output port, so you won't be able to use this method if you have a PS4 Slim.

steps.headline: Plug one end of the audio cable into your speakers' optical port.
steps.description: The port resembles the end of the optical audio cable. You should be able to find this port on the back of the main speaker unit. If your speaker doesn't have an optical port, you can buy an optical adapter. For example, you would use an optical-to-RCA adapter to connect an optical cable to traditional red-and-white (analog stereo) speaker ports.

steps.headline: Plug the other end of the cable into your PS4's optical port.
steps.description: This port is on the far-left side of the back of the PS4 while facing it.

steps.headline: Turn on your PS4.
steps.description: You should be able to hear the PS4 menu music through your speakers after a moment. If you don't hear anything, adjust your speakers' volume.

steps.headline: Buy an audio extractor.
steps.description: Audio extractors typically have two HDMI ports on opposite sides, as well as audio-out ports for either optical, 3.5mm stereo, or RCA audio cables. You can find audio extractors online or in some tech department stores. Make sure your extractor's audio output (e.g., RCA) matches your speakers' audio input. Be aware that the audio quality you will receive from an audio extractor will be inferior to the quality you would receive from plugging into your speakers.

steps.headline: Buy an audio cable to connect the extractor and your speakers.
steps.description: This cable must match your extractor's audio output and your speakers' audio input.

steps.headline: Buy an additional HDMI cable.
steps.description: The TV cable that came with your PS4 is an HDMI cable, but you'll need an extra one to connect the audio extractor to the TV.

steps.headline: Plug the PS4 into the audio extractor with the first HDMI cable.
steps.description: This cable goes in the "HDMI" slot that's on the left side of the back of the PS4 while you're facing it, and the "Audio In" HDMI port on the extractor.

steps.headline: Plug the audio extractor into the TV with the second HDMI cable.
steps.description: This HDMI cable connects from the audio extractor's "Audio Out" port to the TV's HDMI port.

steps.headline: Plug the audio extractor into the speakers with the audio cable.
steps.description: The audio cable will connect from the extractor's audio output to the speakers' audio input.

steps.headline: Turn on your PS4.
steps.description: You should be able to hear the PS4 menu music through your speakers after a moment. If you don't hear anything, adjust your speakers' volume.

steps.headline: Buy an auxiliary cable.
steps.description: Aux cables, also known as 3.5 millimeter male-to-male cables, are audio cables with headphone jacks on each end. If you have a pair of headphones which already uses a 3.5 millimeter cable, skip this step and the next one. You can find a 3.5 millimeter cable male-to-male audio cable at most automotive stores, tech departments, or online shops (e.g., Amazon).

steps.headline: Plug the auxiliary cable into headphones.
steps.description: You'll usually find this port on one of the headphone set's sides.

steps.headline: Plug the other end of the cable into your controller.
steps.description: The headphone port on your PS4's controller is on the back of the controller, between the two handles. If you have a pair of headphones which uses a hardwired auxiliary cable, just plug that into the controller.

steps.headline: Turn on your PS4 and a connected controller.
steps.description: You can do so by pressing the PS button on the connected controller.

steps.headline: Select an account and press X.
steps.description: This will log you into the PS4.

steps.headline: Scroll up.
steps.description: Doing so brings up the PS4 menu bar.

steps.headline: Select Settings and press X.
steps.description: Settings is on the far-right side of the menu bar.

steps.headline: Scroll down to select Devices and press X.
steps.description: It's near the bottom of the page.

steps.headline: Select Audio Devices and press X.
steps.description: You'll see this option near the top of the page.

steps.headline: Select Output to Headphones and press X.
steps.description: This option is near the bottom of the page. If your aux cable isn't connected to your PS4 controller, this option will be greyed out.

steps.headline: Select All Audio and press X.
steps.description: This will ensure that all audio played on your PS4 comes through the headphone jack rather than through the TV's speakers.

steps.headline: Press the PS button.
steps.description: Now the sound from any media viewed on the PS4 will play through the cable, thereby using your headphones as an output point.

steps.headline: Buy an auxiliary cable.
steps.description: Unfortunately, Sony doesn't allow you to connect your Bluetooth speaker to your PS4 via Bluetooth, but you can use a 3.5 millimeter audio cable (also known as an auxiliary cable) to hard-wire your speaker. Short of buying a Bluetooth transmitter which may or may not by supported by your PS4, there is no way to connect your Bluetooth (wireless) speaker to your PS4 without a cable. Virtually all Bluetooth speakers have a headphone jack somewhere on them for manual access. If for some reason your speaker doesn't have an audio jack (or the audio jack is broken), you can't use it with your PS4.

steps.headline: Attach the speaker to your PS4 controller.
steps.description: Plug one end of the 3.5 millimeter cable into the headphone jack on the back of your PS4 controller, then plug the other end into the "Audio In" (or "Line In", or similar) jack on the back of your Bluetooth speaker.

steps.headline: Turn on and sign into your PS4.
steps.description: Press the PS button on your synced PS4 controller to turn on the PS4, then select your profile and press X.

steps.headline: Open Settings.
steps.description: Scroll up to the menu bar, then scroll right to select the briefcase-shaped Settings icon and press X.

steps.headline: Scroll down and select Devices.
steps.description: It's about halfway down the Settings page.

steps.headline: Select Audio Devices.
steps.description: You'll find this option near the top of the Devices page.

steps.headline: Select Output Device.
steps.description: This is near the top of the Audio Devices page.

steps.headline: Select Headset Connected to Controller.
steps.description: You'll find it on the right side of the screen. Depending on your other PS4 settings, this option may already be selected.

steps.headline: Select Output to Headphones.
steps.description: It's near the bottom of the screen.

steps.headline: Select All Audio.
steps.description: This option is on the far-right side of the screen. Doing so ensures that all audio from your PS4 will be output through your controller, meaning that it should go through the connected speaker.

steps.headline: Turn on your speaker.
